feed.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to give food to a person or animal
feed.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She was too weak to feed herself.
Several children were feeding bread to the ducks.
They were fed well on her mother’s home cooking.
feed.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to provide enough food for a group of people
feed.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: groceries to feed a family of five
The prison is required to feed and clothe the prisoners.
feed.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to give a special substance to a plant, which helps it grow
feed.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Feed the tomatoes once a week.
Feed houseplants with a liquid fertilizer.
feed.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if a baby or an animal feeds, they eat
feed.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Let your baby feed as long as she wants.
feed.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to put information into a computer over a period of time
feed.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Figures are fed into the computer, which then predicts the likely profit.
feed.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to supply something, especially a liquid, gas, or electricity
feed.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: The public baths are fed by natural springs.
The sound is fed directly to the headphones.
Laura crouched by the fire, feeding it with dry sticks.
feed.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to put something into something else, especially gradually and through a small hole
feed.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: A tube was fed down the patient’s throat into her stomach.
She fed her last two coins into the machine for a cup of coffee.
feed.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to increase the strength of an emotion, desire etc
feed.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Her depression grew, fed by her bitter experiences.
feed.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to give someone information or ideas over a period time
feed.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: She feeds the media with stories, which is a way of getting free advertising.
US intelligence had been feeding false information to a KGB agent.
feed.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to throw or hit a ball to someone else on your team, especially so that they can make a point
feed.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: He fed the ball to Jol, who scored.
feed.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to send a television or radio programme somewhere so that it can be broadcast
feed.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: one of the times when you give milk to a small baby
feed.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a tube or piece of equipment which supplies a machine with something, especially fuel
feed.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: when a television or radio signal, computer information etc is sent somewhere, or the connection that is used to do this
feed.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: a live satellite feed from the space station
feed.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to pass to a later stage in a process or system
feed.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The data is fed into computers for analysis.
Tax increases and spending curbs by state and local governments feed into the private sector.
Reductions in corporation tax, which are still feeding through the economy, will be worth £1 billion to industry in the next year.
Growth across the portfolio was 7%, which feeds through into higher dividend income.
feed.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a way of supplying something that is needed for a particular process or activity
feed.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Traders on each of the four markets will be able to view listings on the others via a common data feed.
feed.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: a television or radio signal, computer information etc is sent somewhere, or the connection that is used to do this
feed.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: a live satellite feed from the White House
